author: zahary.
content:
<@387720149345763329>, Nimbus's workflow is very similar as well. All you have to do is:

```
beacon_node deposits import <some-directory>
```

it will scan the sub-directories recursively for keystore files and it will import them in our own database. If the keystores are password-protected, you'll be asked to provide the password interactively

author: ajsutton
content: Teku just needs you to give us the path to your keystores and we'll read them from there.  No import necessary.

author: bobcat6146
content:
> Hi <@!387720149345763329> you should be able to import keystore files created in lighthouse, what errors do you get if you use the prysm.sh validator accounts-v2 import command ?
<@!311971895828283393> not working. message:

author: bobcat6146
content:
**Importing accounts, this may take a while...

Please try again, could not use password to import account 0x9092dff7283b:**

author: bobcat6146
content: plain text password was provided, however, looks like lighthouse does not use that plaintext directly, instead, it uses encrypted plaintext -- it encrypt the plaintext password first, then save it to a file under secrects folder, then use that file to decrypt keystore.

author: bobcat6146
content: when i input the encrypted password, such as *nONOQvpPuQ07xn3dUawmVOc0lxcvQ3xvBFiTYm5LbstfPlZu*, error:

author: bobcat6146
content: Also, although a batch use same pass-phase, each keysore has a different encrypted  password file generated.

author: bobcat6146
content: i'm using lighthouse to batch generate keystores and do batch deposit.
